caret-position.name: CaretPosition
caret-position.summary: The CaretPosition interface represents the caret position, an indicator for the text insertion point. You can get a CaretPosition using the document.caretPositionFromPoint method.
caret-position.title: CaretPosition

scrolling-events.name: scroll_event
scrolling-events.summary: The scroll event fires when the document view or an element has been scrolled.
scrolling-events.title: Document: scroll event

scrolling-events.name: scroll_event
scrolling-events.summary: The scroll event fires an element has been scrolled.
scrolling-events.title: Element: scroll event

dom-document-scrollingelement.name: scrollingElement
dom-document-scrollingelement.summary: The scrollingElement read-only property of the Document interface returns a reference to the Element that scrolls the document. In standards mode, this is the root element of the document, document.documentElement.
dom-document-scrollingelement.title: Document.scrollingElement

extensions-to-the-document-interface.name: Document
extensions-to-the-document-interface.summary: The Document interface represents any web page loaded in the browser and serves as an entry point into the web page's content, which is the DOM tree.
extensions-to-the-document-interface.title: Document

dom-document-caretpositionfrompoint.name: caretPositionFromPoint
dom-document-caretpositionfrompoint.summary: The caretPositionFromPoint() property of the DocumentOrShadowRoot interface returns a CaretPosition object, containing the DOM node, along with the caret and caret's character offset within that node.
dom-document-caretpositionfrompoint.title: DocumentOrShadowRoot.caretPositionFromPoint()

dom-document-elementsfrompoint.name: elementFromPoint
dom-document-elementsfrompoint.summary: The elementFromPoint() method—available on both the Document and ShadowRoot objects—returns the topmost Element at the specified coordinates (relative to the viewport).

chrome.notes: Before Chrome 66, this method returned null when the element was a child of a host node. See issue 759947.

chrome_android.notes: Before Chrome 66, this method returned null when the element was a child of a host node. See issue 759947.

samsunginternet_android.notes: Before Samsung Internet 9.0, this method returned null when the element was a child of a host node. See issue 759947.

webview_android.notes: Before WebView 66, this method returned null when the element was a child of a host node. See issue 759947.

edge_blink.notes: Before Chrome 66, this method returned null when the element was a child of a host node. See issue 759947.

dom-document-elementsfrompoint.title: DocumentOrShadowRoot.elementFromPoint()

dom-document-elementsfrompoint.name: elementsFromPoint
dom-document-elementsfrompoint.summary: The elementsFromPoint() method of the DocumentOrShadowRoot interface returns an array of all elements at the specified coordinates (relative to the viewport).

chrome.notes: Before Chrome 66, this method returned null when the element was a child of a host node. See issue 759947.

chrome_android.notes: Before Chrome 66, this method returned null when the element was a child of a host node. See issue 759947.

ie.notes: Returns a NodeList instead of an array. See the MSDN documentation. Returns null when the point provided has no elements beneath it (e.g., when given a point outside the document).

samsunginternet_android.notes: Before Samsung Internet 9.0, this method returned null when the element was a child of a host node. See issue 759947.

webview_android.notes: Before WebView 66, this method returned null when the element was a child of a host node. See issue 759947.

edge_blink.notes: Before Chrome 66, this method returned null when the element was a child of a host node. See issue 759947.

dom-document-elementsfrompoint.title: DocumentOrShadowRoot.elementsFromPoint()

dom-element-clientheight.name: clientHeight
dom-element-clientheight.summary: The Element.clientHeight read-only property is zero for elements with no CSS or inline layout boxes; otherwise, it's the inner height of an element in pixels. It includes padding but excludes borders, margins, and horizontal scrollbars (if present).
dom-element-clientheight.title: Element.clientHeight

dom-element-clientleft.name: clientLeft
dom-element-clientleft.summary: The width of the left border of an element in pixels. It includes the width of the vertical scrollbar if the text direction of the element is right–to–left and if there is an overflow causing a left vertical scrollbar to be rendered. clientLeft does not include the left margin or the left padding. clientLeft is read-only.
dom-element-clientleft.title: Element.clientLeft

dom-element-clienttop.name: clientTop
dom-element-clienttop.summary: The width of the top border of an element in pixels. It is a read-only, integer property of element.
dom-element-clienttop.title: Element.clientTop

dom-element-clientwidth.name: clientWidth
dom-element-clientwidth.summary: The Element.clientWidth property is zero for inline elements and elements with no CSS; otherwise, it's the inner width of an element in pixels. It includes padding but excludes borders, margins, and vertical scrollbars (if present).
dom-element-clientwidth.title: Element.clientWidth

dom-element-getboundingclientrect.name: getBoundingClientRect
dom-element-getboundingclientrect.summary: The Element.getBoundingClientRect() method returns the size of an element and its position relative to the viewport.

safari_ios.notes: Safari for iOS will modify the effective viewport based on the user zoom. This results in incorrect values whenever the user has zoomed.

dom-element-getboundingclientrect.title: Element.getBoundingClientRect()

dom-element-getclientrects.name: getClientRects
dom-element-getclientrects.summary: The getClientRects() method of the Element interface returns a collection of DOMRect objects that indicate the bounding rectangles for each CSS border box in a client.
dom-element-getclientrects.title: Element.getClientRects()

dom-element-scroll-options-options.name: scroll
dom-element-scroll-options-options.summary: The scroll() method of the Element interface scrolls the element to a particular set of coordinates inside a given element.
dom-element-scroll-options-options.title: Element.scroll()

dom-element-scrollby-options-options.name: scrollBy
dom-element-scrollby-options-options.summary: The scrollBy() method of the Element interface scrolls an element by the given amount.
dom-element-scrollby-options-options.title: Element.scrollBy()

dom-element-scrollheight.name: scrollHeight
dom-element-scrollheight.summary: The Element.scrollHeight read-only property is a measurement of the height of an element's content, including content not visible on the screen due to overflow.

firefox.notes: In Firefox versions prior to 21, when an element's content does not generate a vertical scrollbar, then its scrollHeight property is equal to its clientHeight property. This can mean either the content is too short to require a scrollbar or that the element has a CSS style overflow value of visible (non-scrollable).

firefox_android.notes: In Firefox versions prior to 21, when an element's content does not generate a vertical scrollbar, then its scrollHeight property is equal to its clientHeight property. This can mean either the content is too short to require a scrollbar or that the element has a CSS style overflow value of visible (non-scrollable).

ie.notes: In Internet Explorer 5 through 7, if padding is set, the value of scrollHeight is equal to the sum of the top and bottom padding. This behavior was fixed in Internet Explorer 8.

dom-element-scrollheight.title: Element.scrollHeight

dom-element-scrollintoview.name: scrollIntoView
dom-element-scrollintoview.summary: The Element interface's scrollIntoView() method scrolls the element's parent container such that the element on which scrollIntoView() is called is visible to the user

notes: This function is implemented in the HTMLElement API, meaning non-HTML elements (like SVG elements) cannot use this function.
No support for smooth behavior or center options.

safari.notes: No support for smooth behavior or center options.

safari_ios.notes: No support for smooth behavior or center options.

dom-element-scrollintoview.title: Element.scrollIntoView()

dom-element-scrollleft.name: scrollLeft
dom-element-scrollleft.summary: The Element.scrollLeft property gets or sets the number of pixels that an element's content is scrolled from its left edge.

chrome.notes: For right-to-left elements, this property uses 0-100 (most left to most right) instead of negative values. See bug 721759.

chrome_android.notes: For right-to-left elements, this property uses 0-100 (most left to most right) instead of negative values. See bug 721759.

ie.notes: For right-to-left elements, this property uses 100-0 (most left to most right) instead of negative values.

webview_android.notes: For right-to-left elements, this property uses 0-100 (most left to most right) instead of negative values. See bug 721759.

edge_blink.notes: For right-to-left elements, this property uses 0-100 (most left to most right) instead of negative values. See bug 721759.

dom-element-scrollleft.title: Element.scrollLeft

dom-element-scrollto-options-options.name: scrollTo
dom-element-scrollto-options-options.summary: The scrollTo() method of the Element interface scrolls to a particular set of coordinates inside a given element.
dom-element-scrollto-options-options.title: Element.scrollTo()

dom-element-scrolltop.name: scrollTop
dom-element-scrolltop.summary: The Element.scrollTop property gets or sets the number of pixels that an element's content is scrolled vertically.
dom-element-scrolltop.title: Element.scrollTop

dom-element-scrollwidth.name: scrollWidth
dom-element-scrollwidth.summary: The Element.scrollWidth read-only property is a measurement of the width of an element's content, including content not visible on the screen due to overflow.

ie.notes: In Internet Explorer 5 through 7, if padding is set, the value of scrollWidth is equal to the sum of the left and right padding. This behavior was fixed in Internet Explorer 8.

dom-element-scrollwidth.title: Element.scrollWidth

extension-to-the-element-interface.name: Element
extension-to-the-element-interface.summary: Element is the most general base class from which all element objects (i.e. objects that represent elements) in a Document inherit. It only has methods and properties common to all kinds of elements. More specific classes inherit from Element.
extension-to-the-element-interface.title: Element

the-geometryutils-interface.name: GeometryUtils
the-geometryutils-interface.summary: The GeometryUtils interface provides different utility function to retrieve geometry information about DOM nodes.
the-geometryutils-interface.title: GeometryUtils

dom-htmlelement-offsetheight.name: offsetHeight
dom-htmlelement-offsetheight.summary: The HTMLElement.offsetHeight read-only property returns the height of an element, including vertical padding and borders, as an integer.
dom-htmlelement-offsetheight.title: HTMLElement.offsetHeight

dom-htmlelement-offsetleft.name: offsetLeft
dom-htmlelement-offsetleft.summary: The HTMLElement.offsetLeft read-only property returns the number of pixels that the upper left corner of the current element is offset to the left within the HTMLElement.offsetParent node.
dom-htmlelement-offsetleft.title: HTMLElement.offsetLeft

dom-htmlelement-offsetparent.name: offsetParent
dom-htmlelement-offsetparent.summary: The HTMLElement.offsetParent read-only property returns a reference to the element which is the closest (nearest in the containment hierarchy) positioned ancestor element. If there is no positioned ancestor element, the nearest ancestor td, th, table will be returned, or the body if there are no ancestor table elements either.
dom-htmlelement-offsetparent.title: HTMLElement.offsetParent

dom-htmlelement-offsettop.name: offsetTop
dom-htmlelement-offsettop.summary: The HTMLElement.offsetTop read-only property returns the distance of the current element relative to the top of the offsetParent node.
dom-htmlelement-offsettop.title: HTMLElement.offsetTop

dom-htmlelement-offsetwidth.name: offsetWidth
dom-htmlelement-offsetwidth.summary: The HTMLElement.offsetWidth read-only property returns the layout width of an element as an integer.
dom-htmlelement-offsetwidth.title: HTMLElement.offsetWidth

extensions-to-the-htmlelement-interface.name: HTMLElement
extensions-to-the-htmlelement-interface.summary: The HTMLElement interface represents any HTML element. Some elements directly implement this interface, while others implement it via an interface that inherits it.
extensions-to-the-htmlelement-interface.title: HTMLElement

dom-htmlimageelement-x.name: x
dom-htmlimageelement-x.summary: The read-only HTMLImageElement property x indicates the x-coordinate of the element's left border edge relative to the root element's origin.
dom-htmlimageelement-x.title: HTMLImageElement.x

dom-htmlimageelement-y.name: y
dom-htmlimageelement-y.summary: The read-only HTMLImageElement property y indicates the y-coordinate of the element's top border edge relative to the root element's origin.
dom-htmlimageelement-y.title: HTMLImageElement.y

extensions-to-the-htmlimageelement-inter.name: HTMLImageElement
extensions-to-the-htmlimageelement-inter.summary: The HTMLImageElement interface represents an HTML element, providing the properties and methods used to manipulate image elements.
extensions-to-the-htmlimageelement-inter.title: HTMLImageElement

dom-mediaquerylist-addlistener.name: addListener
dom-mediaquerylist-addlistener.summary: The addListener() method of the MediaQueryList interface adds a listener to the MediaQueryListener that will run a custom callback function in response to the media query status changing.

safari.notes: Prior to Safari 14, MediaQueryList is based on EventTarget, so you must use addListener() and removeListener() to observe media query lists.

safari_ios.notes: Prior to Safari 14, MediaQueryList is based on EventTarget, so you must use addListener() and removeListener() to observe media query lists.

dom-mediaquerylist-addlistener.title: MediaQueryList.addListener()

dom-mediaquerylist-matches.name: matches
dom-mediaquerylist-matches.summary: The matches read-only property of the MediaQueryList interface is a Boolean that returns true if the document currently matches the media query list, or false if not.
dom-mediaquerylist-matches.title: MediaQueryList.matches

dom-mediaquerylist-media.name: media
dom-mediaquerylist-media.summary: The media read-only property of the MediaQueryList interface is a DOMString representing a serialized media query.
dom-mediaquerylist-media.title: MediaQueryList.media

dom-mediaquerylist-onchange.name: onchange
dom-mediaquerylist-onchange.summary: The onchange property of the MediaQueryList interface is an event handler property representing a function that is invoked when the change event fires, i.e when the status of media query support changes. The event object is a MediaQueryListEvent instance, which is recognised as a MediaListQuery instance in older browsers, for backwards compatibility purposes.
dom-mediaquerylist-onchange.title: MediaQueryList.onchange

dom-mediaquerylist-removelistener.name: removeListener
dom-mediaquerylist-removelistener.summary: The removeListener() method of the MediaQueryList interface removes a listener from the MediaQueryListener.

safari.notes: Prior to Safari 14, MediaQueryList is based on EventTarget, so you must use addListener() and removeListener() to observe media query lists.

safari_ios.notes: Prior to Safari 14, MediaQueryList is based on EventTarget, so you must use addListener() and removeListener() to observe media query lists.

dom-mediaquerylist-removelistener.title: MediaQueryList.removeListener()

the-mediaquerylist-interface.name: MediaQueryList
the-mediaquerylist-interface.summary: A MediaQueryList object stores information on a media query applied to a document, with support for both immediate and event-driven matching against the state of the document.

safari.notes: Prior to Safari 14, MediaQueryList is based on EventTarget, so you must use addListener() and removeListener() to observe media query lists.

safari_ios.notes: Prior to Safari 14, MediaQueryList is based on EventTarget, so you must use addListener() and removeListener() to observe media query lists.

the-mediaquerylist-interface.title: MediaQueryList

the-mediaquerylist-interface.name: MediaQueryListListener
the-mediaquerylist-interface.summary: A MediaQueryList object maintains a list of media queries on a Document, and handles sending notifications to listeners when the media queries on the document change.
the-mediaquerylist-interface.title: MediaQueryListListener

dom-mediaquerylistevent-mediaquerylistev.name: MediaQueryListEvent
dom-mediaquerylistevent-mediaquerylistev.summary: The MediaQueryListEvent constructor creates a new MediaQueryListEvent instance.
dom-mediaquerylistevent-mediaquerylistev.title: MediaQueryListEvent.MediaQueryListEvent()

dom-mediaquerylistevent-matches.name: matches
dom-mediaquerylistevent-matches.summary: The matches read-only property of the MediaQueryListEvent interface is a Boolean that returns true if the document currently matches the media query list, or false if not.
dom-mediaquerylistevent-matches.title: MediaQueryListEvent.matches

dom-mediaquerylistevent-media.name: media
dom-mediaquerylistevent-media.summary: The media read-only property of the MediaQueryListEvent interface is a DOMString representing a serialized media query.
dom-mediaquerylistevent-media.title: MediaQueryListEvent.media

mediaquerylistevent.name: MediaQueryListEvent
mediaquerylistevent.summary: The MediaQueryListEvent object stores information on the changes that have happened to a MediaQueryList object — instances are available as the event object on a function referenced by a MediaQueryList.onchange property or MediaQueryList.addListener() call.
mediaquerylistevent.title: MediaQueryListEvent

extensions-to-the-mouseevent-interface.name: MouseEvent
extensions-to-the-mouseevent-interface.summary: The MouseEvent() constructor creates a new MouseEvent.
extensions-to-the-mouseevent-interface.title: MouseEvent()

extensions-to-the-mouseevent-interface.name: MouseEvent
extensions-to-the-mouseevent-interface.summary: The MouseEvent interface represents events that occur due to the user interacting with a pointing device (such as a mouse). Common events using this interface include click, dblclick, mouseup, mousedown.
extensions-to-the-mouseevent-interface.title: MouseEvent

extensions-to-the-mouseevent-interface.name: MouseEvent
extensions-to-the-mouseevent-interface.summary: The MouseEvent interface represents events that occur due to the user interacting with a pointing device (such as a mouse). Common events using this interface include click, dblclick, mouseup, mousedown.
extensions-to-the-mouseevent-interface.title: MouseEvent

extensions-to-the-mouseevent-interface.name: pointerType
extensions-to-the-mouseevent-interface.summary: The pointerType read-only property of the PointerEvent interface indicates the device type (mouse, pen, or touch) that caused a given pointer event.

ie.notes: Returns an integer enumeration instead of a string.

extensions-to-the-mouseevent-interface.title: PointerEvent.pointerType

dom-mouseevent-clientx.name: clientX
dom-mouseevent-clientx.summary: The clientX read-only property of the MouseEvent interface provides the horizontal coordinate within the application's viewport at which the event occurred (as opposed to the coordinate within the page).
dom-mouseevent-clientx.title: MouseEvent.clientX

dom-mouseevent-clienty.name: clientY
dom-mouseevent-clienty.summary: The clientY read-only property of the MouseEvent interface provides the vertical coordinate within the application's viewport at which the event occurred (as opposed to the coordinate within the page).
dom-mouseevent-clienty.title: MouseEvent.clientY

dom-mouseevent-offsetx.name: offsetX
dom-mouseevent-offsetx.summary: The offsetX read-only property of the MouseEvent interface provides the offset in the X coordinate of the mouse pointer between that event and the padding edge of the target node.
dom-mouseevent-offsetx.title: MouseEvent.offsetX

dom-mouseevent-offsety.name: offsetY
dom-mouseevent-offsety.summary: The offsetY read-only property of the MouseEvent interface provides the offset in the Y coordinate of the mouse pointer between that event and the padding edge of the target node.
dom-mouseevent-offsety.title: MouseEvent.offsetY

dom-mouseevent-pagex.name: pageX
dom-mouseevent-pagex.summary: The pageX read-only property of the MouseEvent interface returns the X (horizontal) coordinate (in pixels) at which the mouse was clicked, relative to the left edge of the entire document.
dom-mouseevent-pagex.title: MouseEvent.pageX

dom-mouseevent-pagey.name: pageY
dom-mouseevent-pagey.summary: The pageY read-only property of the MouseEvent interface returns the Y (vertical) coordinate in pixels of the event relative to the whole document. This property takes into account any vertical scrolling of the page.
dom-mouseevent-pagey.title: MouseEvent.pageY

dom-mouseevent-screenx.name: screenX
dom-mouseevent-screenx.summary: The screenX read-only property of the MouseEvent interface provides the horizontal coordinate (offset) of the mouse pointer in global (screen) coordinates.
dom-mouseevent-screenx.title: MouseEvent.screenX

dom-mouseevent-screeny.name: screenY
dom-mouseevent-screeny.summary: The screenY read-only property of the MouseEvent interface provides the vertical coordinate (offset) of the mouse pointer in global (screen) coordinates.
dom-mouseevent-screeny.title: MouseEvent.screenY

dom-mouseevent-x.name: x
dom-mouseevent-x.summary: The MouseEvent.x property is an alias for the MouseEvent.clientX property.
dom-mouseevent-x.title: MouseEvent.x

dom-mouseevent-y.name: y
dom-mouseevent-y.summary: The MouseEvent.y property is an alias for the MouseEvent.clientY property.
dom-mouseevent-y.title: MouseEvent.y

dom-range-getboundingclientrect.name: getBoundingClientRect
dom-range-getboundingclientrect.summary: The Range.getBoundingClientRect() method returns a DOMRect object that bounds the contents of the range; this is a rectangle enclosing the union of the bounding rectangles for all the elements in the range.
dom-range-getboundingclientrect.title: Range.getBoundingClientRect()

dom-range-getclientrects.name: getClientRects
dom-range-getclientrects.summary: The Range.getClientRects() method returns a list of DOMRect objects representing the area of the screen occupied by the range. This is created by aggregating the results of calls to Element.getClientRects() for all the elements in the range.
dom-range-getclientrects.title: Range.getClientRects()

extensions-to-the-range-interface.name: Range
extensions-to-the-range-interface.summary: The Range interface represents a fragment of a document that can contain nodes and parts of text nodes.

firefox.notes: Starting with Firefox 13, the Range object throws a DOMException as defined in DOM 4, instead of a RangeException defined in prior specifications.

firefox_android.notes: Starting with Firefox 13, the Range object throws a DOMException as defined in DOM 4, instead of a RangeException defined in prior specifications.

extensions-to-the-range-interface.title: Range

dom-screen-availheight.name: availHeight
dom-screen-availheight.summary: The read-only Screen interface's availHeight property returns the height, in CSS pixels, of the space available for Web content on the screen. Since Screen is exposed on the Window interface's window.screen property, you access availHeight using window.screen.availHeight.
dom-screen-availheight.title: Screen.availHeight

dom-screen-availwidth.name: availWidth
dom-screen-availwidth.summary: The Screen.availWidth property returns the amount of horizontal space (in pixels) available to the window.
dom-screen-availwidth.title: Screen.availWidth

dom-screen-colordepth.name: colorDepth
dom-screen-colordepth.summary: The Screen.colorDepth read-only property returns the color depth of the screen. Per the CSSOM, some implementations return 24 for compatibility reasons. See the browser compatibility section for those that don't.

chrome.notes: Starting with version 59 this property is no longer required to always return 24.

chrome_android.notes: Starting with version 59 this property is no longer required to always return 24.

samsunginternet_android.notes: Starting with Samsung Internet 7.0 this property is no longer required to always return 24.

webview_android.notes: Starting with version 59 this property is no longer required to always return 24.

edge_blink.notes: Starting with version 59 this property is no longer required to always return 24.

dom-screen-colordepth.title: Screen.colorDepth

dom-screen-height.name: height
dom-screen-height.summary: The Screen.height read-only property returns the height of the screen in pixels.
dom-screen-height.title: Screen.height

dom-screen-pixeldepth.name: pixelDepth
dom-screen-pixeldepth.summary: Returns the bit depth of the screen. Per the CSSOM, some implementations return 24 for compatibility reasons. See the browser compatibility section for those that don't.

chrome.notes: Starting with version 59 this property is no longer required to always return 24.

chrome_android.notes: Starting with version 59 this property is no longer required to always return 24.

samsunginternet_android.notes: Starting with Samsung Internet 7.0 this property is no longer required to always return 24.

webview_android.notes: Starting with version 59 this property is no longer required to always return 24.

edge_blink.notes: Starting with version 59 this property is no longer required to always return 24.

dom-screen-pixeldepth.title: Screen.pixelDepth

dom-screen-width.name: width
dom-screen-width.summary: The Screen.width read-only property returns the width of the screen in pixels.
dom-screen-width.title: Screen.width

the-screen-interface.name: Screen
the-screen-interface.summary: The Screen interface represents a screen, usually the one on which the current window is being rendered, and is obtained using window.screen.
the-screen-interface.title: Screen

dictdef-scrolloptions.name: behavior
dictdef-scrolloptions.summary: An enum, the value of which can be one of the following:

safari.notes: Safari does not have support for the smooth scroll behavior.

safari_ios.notes: Safari does not have support for the smooth scroll behavior.

dictdef-scrolloptions.title: ScrollToOptions.behavior

dictdef-scrolltooptions.name: ScrollToOptions
dictdef-scrolltooptions.summary: The ScrollToOptions dictionary of the CSSOM View spec contains properties specifying where an element should be scrolled to, and whether the scrolling should be smooth.
dictdef-scrolltooptions.title: ScrollToOptions

dom-window-devicepixelratio.name: devicePixelRatio
dom-window-devicepixelratio.summary: The devicePixelRatio of Window interface returns the ratio of the resolution in physical pixels to the resolution in CSS pixels for the current display device.
dom-window-devicepixelratio.title: Window.devicePixelRatio

dom-window-innerheight.name: innerHeight
dom-window-innerheight.summary: The read-only innerHeight property of the Window interface returns the interior height of the window in pixels, including the height of the horizontal scroll bar, if present.

firefox.notes: This property was buggy and could give a wrong value before page load in certain circumstances, see bug 641188.

firefox_android.notes: This property was buggy and could give a wrong value before page load in certain circumstances, see bug 641188.

safari_ios.notes: This property returns the height of the visual viewport instead of the layout viewport. See this bug for details.

dom-window-innerheight.title: Window.innerHeight

dom-window-innerwidth.name: innerWidth
dom-window-innerwidth.summary: The read-only Window property innerWidth returns the interior width of the window in pixels. This includes the width of the vertical scroll bar, if one is present.

firefox.notes: This property was buggy and could give a wrong value before page load in certain circumstances, see bug 641188.

firefox_android.notes: This property was buggy and could give a wrong value before page load in certain circumstances, see bug 641188.

safari_ios.notes: This property returns the width of the visual viewport instead of the layout viewport. See this bug for details.

dom-window-innerwidth.title: Window.innerWidth

dom-window-matchmedia.name: matchMedia
dom-window-matchmedia.summary: The Window interface's matchMedia() method returns a new MediaQueryList object that can then be used to determine if the document matches the media query string, as well as to monitor the document to detect when it matches (or stops matching) that media query.
dom-window-matchmedia.title: Window.matchMedia()

dom-window-moveby.name: moveBy
dom-window-moveby.summary: The moveBy() method of the Window interface moves the current window by a specified amount.
dom-window-moveby.title: Window.moveBy()

dom-window-moveto.name: moveTo
dom-window-moveto.summary: The moveTo() method of the Window interface moves the current window to the specified coordinates.
dom-window-moveto.title: Window.moveTo()

the-features-argument-to-the-open()-meth.name: open
the-features-argument-to-the-open()-meth.summary: The Window interface's open() method loads the specified resource into the new or existing browsing context (window, <iframe> or tab) with the specified name. If the name doesn't exist, then a new browsing context is opened in a new tab or a new window, and the specified resource is loaded into it.
the-features-argument-to-the-open()-meth.title: Window.open()

dom-window-outerheight.name: outerHeight
dom-window-outerheight.summary: The Window.outerHeight read-only property returns the height in pixels of the whole browser window, including any sidebar, window chrome, and window-resizing borders/handles.
dom-window-outerheight.title: Window.outerHeight

dom-window-outerwidth.name: outerWidth
dom-window-outerwidth.summary: Window.outerWidth read-only property returns the width of the outside of the browser window. It represents the width of the whole browser window including sidebar (if expanded), window chrome and window resizing borders/handles.
dom-window-outerwidth.title: Window.outerWidth

dom-window-pagexoffset.name: pageXOffset
dom-window-pagexoffset.summary: The read-only Window property pageXOffset is an alias for scrollX.
dom-window-pagexoffset.title: Window.pageXOffset

dom-window-pageyoffset.name: pageYOffset
dom-window-pageyoffset.summary: The read-only Window property pageYOffset is an alias for scrollY; as such, it returns the number of pixels the document is currently scrolled along the vertical axis (that is, up or down) with a value of 0.0, indicating that the top edge of the Document is currently aligned with the top edge of the window's content area.
dom-window-pageyoffset.title: Window.pageYOffset

resizing-viewports.name: resize_event
resizing-viewports.summary: The resize event fires when the document view (window) has been resized.

chrome.notes: Chrome does not emit a resize event on page load.

chrome_android.notes: Chrome does not emit a resize event on page load.

firefox.notes: Prior to Firefox 68, Firefox emitted a resize event on page load. This is no longer the case.

firefox_android.notes: Prior to Firefox 68, Firefox emitted a resize event on page load. This is no longer the case.

opera.notes: Opera does not emit a resize event on page load.

opera_android.notes: Opera does not emit a resize event on page load.

samsunginternet_android.notes: Samsung Internet does not emit a resize event on page load.

webview_android.notes: Webview does not emit a resize event on page load.

edge_blink.notes: Chrome does not emit a resize event on page load.

resizing-viewports.title: Window: resize event

dom-window-resizeby.name: resizeBy
dom-window-resizeby.summary: The Window.resizeBy() method resizes the current window by a specified amount.

firefox.notes: Since Firefox 7, it's no longer possible for a web site to change the default size of a window in a browser if the window wasn't created by window.open or contains more than one tab. See here for more details.

dom-window-resizeby.title: Window.resizeBy()

dom-window-resizeto.name: resizeTo
dom-window-resizeto.summary: The Window.resizeTo() method dynamically resizes the window.

firefox.notes: Since Firefox 7, it's no longer possible for a web site to change the default size of a window in a browser if the window wasn't created by window.open or contains more than one tab. See here for more details.

dom-window-resizeto.title: Window.resizeTo()

dom-window-screen.name: screen
dom-window-screen.summary: The Window property screen returns a reference to the screen object associated with the window. The screen object, implementing the Screen interface, is a special object for inspecting properties of the screen on which the current window is being rendered.
dom-window-screen.title: Window.screen

dom-window-screenx.name: screenLeft
dom-window-screenx.summary: The Window.screenLeft read-only property returns the horizontal distance, in CSS pixels, from the left border of the user's browser viewport to the left side of the screen.
dom-window-screenx.title: Window.screenLeft

dom-window-screenx.name: screenX
dom-window-screenx.summary: The Window.screenX read-only property returns the horizontal distance, in CSS pixels, of the left border of the user's browser viewport to the left side of the screen.

firefox.notes: Before Firefox 28, Gecko was using device pixels instead of CSS pixels; in other words, it was assuming a value of screenPixelsPerCSSPixel of 1 for any device.

firefox_android.notes: Before Firefox 28, Gecko was using device pixels instead of CSS pixels; in other words, it was assuming a value of screenPixelsPerCSSPixel of 1 for any device.

dom-window-screenx.title: Window.screenX

dom-window-screeny.name: screenTop
dom-window-screeny.summary: The Window.screenTop read-only property returns the vertical distance, in CSS pixels, from the top border of the user's browser viewport to the top side of the screen.
dom-window-screeny.title: Window.screenTop

dom-window-screeny.name: screenY
dom-window-screeny.summary: The Window.screenY read-only property returns the vertical distance, in CSS pixels, of the top border of the user's browser viewport to the top edge of the screen.

firefox.notes: Before Firefox 28, Gecko was using device pixels instead of CSS pixels; in other words, it was assuming a value of screenPixelsPerCSSPixel of 1 for any device.

firefox_android.notes: Before Firefox 28, Gecko was using device pixels instead of CSS pixels; in other words, it was assuming a value of screenPixelsPerCSSPixel of 1 for any device.

dom-window-screeny.title: Window.screenY

dom-window-scroll.name: scroll
dom-window-scroll.summary: The Window.scroll() method scrolls the window to a particular place in the document.
dom-window-scroll.title: Window.scroll()

dom-window-scroll.name: scrollTo
dom-window-scroll.summary: Window.scrollTo() scrolls to a particular set of coordinates in the document.
dom-window-scroll.title: Window.scrollTo()

dom-window-scrollby.name: scrollBy
dom-window-scrollby.summary: The Window.scrollBy() method scrolls the document in the window by the given amount.
dom-window-scrollby.title: Window.scrollBy()

dom-window-scrollx.name: scrollX
dom-window-scrollx.summary: The read-only scrollX property of the Window interface returns the number of pixels that the document is currently scrolled horizontally. This value is subpixel precise in modern browsers, meaning that it isn't necessarily a whole number. You can get the number of pixels the document is scrolled vertically from the scrollY property.
dom-window-scrollx.title: Window.scrollX

dom-window-scrolly.name: scrollY
dom-window-scrolly.summary: The read-only scrollY property of the Window interface returns the number of pixels that the document is currently scrolled vertically.
dom-window-scrolly.title: Window.scrollY

propdef-scroll-behavior.name: scroll-behavior
propdef-scroll-behavior.summary: The scroll-behavior CSS property sets the behavior for a scrolling box when scrolling is triggered by the navigation or CSSOM scrolling APIs.
propdef-scroll-behavior.title: scroll-behavior
